body:
## Steps to Reproduce

If I type this:
```dart
class StatefulTest extends StatefulWidget {
}
```
Into a dart file, I get an analyzer error on the "StatefulTest":
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8867023/39783798-0bbd949a-52cb-11e8-9115-e44bd2bed8c8.png)

This makes sense.  But when I select "Generate...>Override Methods...", or hit "Ctrl-O", (with my cursor on the class name), I get this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8867023/39783779-030b847e-52cb-11e8-874c-5b3a9a7625a1.png)

I'd really like to be able to easily create a new widget by just typing the class declaration, and then making skeletons of all the missing overrides.

## Version info

```
[âœ“] Flutter (Channel switcher_perf, v0.4.1-pre.32, on Linux, locale en_US.UTF-8)
    â€¢ Flutter version 0.4.1-pre.32 at /usr/local/google/home/gspencer/code/flutter
    â€¢ Framework revision 7cc7263ef8 (4 days ago), 2018-05-04 09:23:45 -0700
    â€¢ Engine revision 20b286dd42
    â€¢ Dart version 2.0.0-dev.53.0.flutter-e6d7d67f4b

[âœ“] Android toolchain - develop for Android devices (Android SDK 27.0.2)
    â€¢ Android SDK at /usr/local/google/home/gspencer/Android/Sdk
    â€¢ Android NDK at /usr/local/google/home/gspencer/Android/Sdk/ndk-bundle
    â€¢ Platform android-27, build-tools 27.0.2
    â€¢ ANDROID_HOME = /usr/local/google/home/gspencer/Android/Sdk
    â€¢ Java binary at: /opt/android-studio-with-blaze-3.0/jre/bin/java
    â€¢ Java version OpenJDK Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_152-release-915-b01)
    â€¢ All Android licenses accepted.

[âœ“] IntelliJ IDEA Community Edition (version 2018.1)
    â€¢ IntelliJ at /opt/my-intellij-ce-2018.1
    â€¢ Flutter plugin version 24.1.2
    â€¢ Dart plugin version 181.4892.1

[âœ“] Connected devices (1 available)
    â€¢ Nexus 6P â€¢ 84B7N15A07007628 â€¢ android-arm64 â€¢ Android 8.1.0 (API 27)

â€¢ No issues found!
```

comment_data.body:
`Generate... > Override Methods...` is implemented in Java in Dart plugin and is old code.
Ideally we should replace it with requesting members data from Analysis Server.
@jwren have you started working on this, or I can steal it? :-)

For you using Quick Assist (Cmd + Enter) might be a  better choice.
It will do exactly what you need - add all missing overrides.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/384794/39797587-9da56ca2-5311-11e8-9ce5-bf59b4640a4b.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/384794/39797607-bcafc4da-5311-11e8-858f-f820258889e2.png)

@scheglov - Go for it.  Integration from DAS into the generator wasn't obvious to me into the Generator IJ framework.  Alt+Enter on the error from the DAS, does the right thing so it hasn't been prioritized.

One difference between the Ctrl/Cmd-I and Alt/Cmd-Enter way is that I have to actually have the cursor on the class name to have the context menu appear, as opposed to anywhere inside of the class declaration.

This issue wasn't fixed yet.

A problem that is quite common to me when I extend a custom created class (like BaseViewModel for example) and want to override any specific method (Ctrl + O) the IDE says that no method where found to override.

This issue still exists in 2020.
When is it going to be fixed?

Any progress? It's really annoying and lowers the work efficiency. ðŸ˜¢ 

And I've found this issue: #1110, but with no luck.

Yeah, I'm not able to get suggestions for overrides still.

If I'm in a class decl between declarations and hit Ctrl-Space, I get a bunch of suggested class names, but no suggested overrides.  Command-O always gives "No methods were found to override". Typing the first few letters of what I want to override and then hitting Ctrl-Space does give me some override suggestions, but then I have to know the exact name (or at least the beginning) of the override, and often I just want to see what is overridable before I pick one.

It would be really nice if Ctrl-Space in a blank area would give me a list of all the possible overrides, and that Command-O was wired up to do the right thing instead of trying to list Java methods or whatever it is doing.

Additionally, I would like to suggest that the templates that the override suggestions place do NOT include the comment that says `// TODO: implement <function>`, since 99.9% of the time I just immediately delete it, making it more work to do (EDIT: actually 100% of the time, since it doesn't match our TODO style guide requirement).  I feel the same way about the "throw UnimplementedError" lines too: I'd rather it insert non-functional code than make me delete it every single time.  Alternatively, once inserted, it could automatically select the body of the function so I could just immediately hit delete or start typing to delete the `throw` line. I still wouldn't want the TODO comments though.
I filed https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/issues/6239 for the "TODO" part of my previous comment.
@stevemessick Should we file a separate Dart issue about the Command/Ctrl-O (Generate...>Override Methods...) behavior?
Yes, it seems to be a regression.

This is a problem in the Dart plugin, and an issue has already been created:
https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/WEB-40469/Dart-Ctrl-O-Override-Methods-does-not-show-Super-class-instance-methods-Dart-Plugin

I'm closing this issue. Whether it will be fixed using the suggestion by @scheglov (above) or by debugging the existing code, the work will be done in the Dart plugin, not the Flutter plugin.

milestone.description: Issues under consideration for upcoming milestones.
milestone.title: On Deck

title: Cannot override missing methods on newly created StatefulWidget
